prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII]-158mu luminosity function at redshift 4<z<6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main aim is to measure [CII]-158micron emission for a sample of 50 galaxies with secure spectroscopic redshifts at 4<z_spec<6. This will be used to derive the [CII] luminosty function for the first time. Using [CII] as a star formation tracer, we will then derive the star formation rate density at 4<z<6 free from systematics plaguing UV-based measurements and provide a much improve constraint for galaxy evolution model right after the reionisation ends.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: setup on CII at the observed redshifts. We use the know redshift of the source, use thee CII 158 microns (1900GHz) to set the correlator
objects are barely resolved, and we priviledge sensitivity

To set the sensitivity for the observations we use the faintest sources in our sample which have an un-obscured SFR of 10 M$_{\odot}$/yr at z$\sim$4.5. Assuming no dust correction and using Carilli \& Yun (1999) we estimate a continuum flux of $>$0.2mJy for these faintest sources in Band 7. Assuming the [CII] line intensity is $0.5 \times 10^{-3}$ (0.1\%) of the FIR flux and a $\sim$200km/s line width we estimate a line flux of $>$0.6mJy. We aim to detect the [CII] line in these sources at $>$3$\sigma$ which will also reach 0.04mJy rms per beam in the continuum, ensuring a $>$7.5$\sigma$ continuum detection. These estimates are for the faintest galaxies; as the average SFR of our sample is 38 M$_{\odot}$/yr, we expect to get a SNR$>$10 on [CII] for most of our sample.
We note that the feasibility of [CII] detection for similar galaxies at z$\sim$$5-6$ is demonstrated by Capak et al. (2015) where all galaxies at z$\sim$5 with SFR$>$25 were detected with 20 min on-source for a 20-antenna ALMA array. The time on source is in-line with these proven observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: setup on CII at the observed redshifts. We use the know redshift of the source, use thee CII 158 microns (1900GHz) to set the correlator
objects are barely resolved, and we privilge sensitivity

To set the sensitivity for the observations we use the faintest sources in our sample which have an un-obscured SFR of 10 M$_{\odot}$/yr at z$\sim$4.5. Assuming no dust correction and using Carilli \& Yun (1999) we estimate a continuum flux of $>$0.2mJy for these faintest sources in Band 7. Assuming the [CII] line intensity is $0.5 \times 10^{-3}$ (0.1\%) of the FIR flux and a $\sim$200km/s line width we estimate a line flux of $>$0.6mJy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to measure [CII]-158$\mu$m emission for a well-defined sample of $\sim50$ galaxies with secure redshifts 4<z_spec<6 from VLT-VIMOS spectroscopy. This will lead to the computation of the [CII]-158micron luminosity function for the first time at these redshifts. Using [CII] luminosity as a star formation rate tracer, this will lead to a measurement of the star formation rate density (SFRD) totally independent from any previous measurement at these redshifts. Compared to other SFRD estimates, derived from FIR continuum emission from the same ALMA observations or from optical+NIR spectral energy distribution fitting, these observations will bring a much needed improvement on the SFRD needed to understand how star formation proceeds at a key epoch in galaxy evolution. This first measurement of the SFRD from [CII] at z~5 will open the path towards using [CII]-based SFR measurements in the epoch of reionisation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
